ygData.msgSnippet: ... I agree that the  should not be overloaded with allowing indexing based on request, that d be too much info to put in there.  It should

	form/authentication entry

On Mon, 2004-01-26 at 14:22, steensc42 wrote:
> --- In archive-crawler@yahoogroups.com, Gordon Mohr <gojomo@a...> 
> wrote:
> > steensc42 wrote:
> > > Here is a proposal for an extension of the arc format in order to 
> > > accommodate more detailed metadata. 
> > [...]
> > I would include these headers, both in the captured request and in
> > any checksum which maps response-to-request.
> > 
> > Servers can vary what they return based on those request headers,
> > and any decision other than recording/checksumming them all requires
> > a volatile judgemental analysis.
> > 
> 
> I agree that the safe approach is to include everything into the 
> checksum.
> From a retrieval point of view this might however pose some problems.
> How do we locate the correct record in the archive to return as 
> response to a post request?
> It would be nice if we could convert the post request into a key that 
> we can locate 
> in an index of archived url-objects. If this key is dependent on all 
> request headers
> it will only work for specific browsers, referrer combinations.
> I guess the answer here is to accept that the <capture-identifier> 
> can not be
> used directly for indexing purposes - and leave the retrieval problem 
> to the
> implementation of the indexing mechanism.

I agree that the <capture-identifier> should not be overloaded with
allowing indexing based on request, that'd be too much info to put in
there.  It should be solely for tying together related records.

> 
> We have another usage scenario we would like this format to support.
> Some of the data formats in the archive may become 
> obsolete/unsupported over time. 
> One approach for handling this problem is storage of applications 
> capable of handling/converting
> these formats. Another approach we want to support is transformation 
> of (important) data at risk
> to formats still supported. An example might be transformation from 
> one graphic file format (say gif),
> to another format (say tif). This might be achieved using "transform" 
> to mark a transformed version:
> 
> 
> transform:http://<url> <dest-ip> <timestamp> <mime> <response-size> 
> <capture-identifier>
> <DATA - transformed version of original data record>
> metadata:transform:http://<url> <dest-ip> <timestamp> <mime> 
> <metadata-size> <capture-identifier>
> <DATA - metadata describing details about the transformation (from 
> format, to format, application, etc)>
> 
> Each time a url-object is transformed a new pair of (transform, 
> metadata:transform) records
> are created, allowing sequences of format transformations.

One issue that we haven't quite resolved yet is what the various header
fields mean in such a context.  <url> is obviously the same as for the
original entry.  <dest-IP> may be the same -- I'm not sure what it's
for, anyway.  <mime> should be the mime-type of the current entry, to
allow correct parsing of the entry.  <response-size> must be the size of
the entry, to allow correct parsing of the ARC file.  But what about
<timestamp>?  Should it be the timestamp of the original, providing an
extra tie-in, or should it be the time that the transform: entry is
written to the ARC file?  Same considerations go for the metadata: and
request: entries.  And the idea is to have the same <capture-identifier>
for all these entries derived from a single http request, right?

Now that I remember it:  The mime-type assigned to the ARC file header
(alexa/arc) and the DAT entries (alexa/dat) does not follow normal mime
rules (see http://www.iana.org/assignments/media-types/).  This may be
considered a minor problem, as they're for internal use, but it ought to
be something like "multipart/vnd.archive.arcfile" and
"text/vnd.archive.dat".  Unless we register them with IANA and can get
"multipart/arcfile" and "text/dat" (unlikely:).

-Lars
